messages:
[{'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2018-09-24 16:15:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-09-24 16:15:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

   helm install --namespace=aqa --name=sonobuoy sonobuoy

is there no pod created from this chart. Also running helm test seems to hang.'}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2018-09-27 18:49:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> I am seeing this: http://paste.openstack.org/show/731039/ when I
 > pull it down and run this via:
 > 
 > helm install --namespace=aqa --name=sonobuoy sonobuoy
 > 
 > is there no pod created from this chart. Also running helm test
 > seems to hang.

Sorry, I should have put that in the commit message (will amend in  a second with instructions).

It needs to be installed in heptio-sonobuoy namespace.

Also, make sure the node it's being ran on matches https://review.openstack.org/#/c/604833/8/sonobuoy/values.yaml@22 .

The only pod that should be created is during helm test."}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2018-09-27 19:01:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2018-09-27 19:09:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Also, the e2e plugin will take about an hour..."}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-10-01 13:17:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

This looks okay to me, but leaving a -1 because I'd like to see this chart executed as an experimental check here in openstack-helm-addons. The reason I'd like to see this is to provide a means to check whether this chart behaves as expected (deploys a release and launched the sonobuoy test pod when `helm test <release>` is executed). At a minimum, this helps ensure this initial addition and any subsequent changes result in a functional chart.  If the other cores disagree, I'll happily remove my -1"}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-10-01 13:23:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2018-10-01 15:52:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2018-10-01 16:02:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2018-10-01 16:09:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

(2 comments)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > This looks okay to me, but leaving a -1 because I'd like to see
 > this chart executed as an experimental check here in
 > openstack-helm-addons. The reason I'd like to see this is to
 > provide a means to check whether this chart behaves as expected
 > (deploys a release and launched the sonobuoy test pod when `helm
 > test <release>` is executed). At a minimum, this helps ensure this
 > initial addition and any subsequent changes result in a functional
 > chart.  If the other cores disagree, I'll happily remove my -1

I'm happy to help with that. Are there any resources or examples? I'll take a look, but I don't have any experience with Zuul -- happy to learn though."}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-10-01 18:52:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > > (1 comment)
 > >
 > > This looks okay to me, but leaving a -1 because I'd like to see
 > > this chart executed as an experimental check here in
 > > openstack-helm-addons. The reason I'd like to see this is to
 > > provide a means to check whether this chart behaves as expected
 > > (deploys a release and launched the sonobuoy test pod when `helm
 > > test <release>` is executed). At a minimum, this helps ensure
 > this
 > > initial addition and any subsequent changes result in a
 > functional
 > > chart.  If the other cores disagree, I'll happily remove my -1
 > 
 > I'm happy to help with that. Are there any resources or examples?
 > I'll take a look, but I don't have any experience with Zuul --
 > happy to learn though.

Sure - it's a pretty simple process, really.  First, you'll need to add a definition for the experimental job in openstack-helm-addon's zuul layout (.zuul.yaml). An example would be the tempest check in openstack-helm: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm/blob/master/.zuul.yaml#L54-L59

Then, you'll need to actually define the check job inside the zuul layout.  We can use the tempest job in openstack-helm as an example here too: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm/blob/master/.zuul.yaml#L240-L245.  The difference here will be that we can use the openstack-helm-ubuntu nodeset instead of the five node nodeset tempest uses.

Finally, you'll need to define a playbook for the job. We can once again use the Tempest experimental job as an example: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm/blob/master/tools/gate/playbooks/multinode-tempest-deploy.yaml. However, the playbook for the sonobuoy check will be fairly simple: you'll likely just have a single script for installing the sonobuoy chart and executing `helm test` on the release to trigger the test. Such a script would live in ./tools/gate/scripts, and could just be something along the lines of `sonobuoy.sh` or whatever you want to call it.

Once you have the job defined and declared as an experimental check in the zuul layout, have included the playbook executed in the playbook directory in openstack-helm-addons, and have a task defined that calls the bash script you're using to install and execute the sonobuoy chart, it should just be a matter of replying "check experimental" on the patchset to actually see the job for sonobuoy kick off.

Let me know if you have any questions - will be happy to delve into this further if necessary.'}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2018-10-01 19:16:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2018-10-01 19:17:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

> is there any way for the gate to pull the tarball in the gate?

Not at the moment. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/604833/19/sonobuoy/templates/pod-api.yaml@97 We're writing the tarball to an empty directory. Locally, I'm changing the empty directory to a hostPath so that I can view the results.

We're having discussions about how to best store this data (persistent volume, object storage, etc.). But I think these changes would be a future commit."}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2018-10-03 15:52:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2018-10-03 15:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

commit_message:
Add Sonobuoy chart

This adds a Sonobuoy chart that only runs the systemd-logs plugin[1]. The
Sonobuoy pod (tests) are executed as a `helm test`.

This chart must be installed under the heptio-sonobuoy namespace[2]. A node
with the label selector specified in values.yaml (labels.api) must exist
for the Sonobuoy pod to even be created.

Also add an experimental job to test Sonobuoy chart.

[1] https://github.com/heptio/sonobuoy-plugin-systemd-logs
[2] https://github.com/heptio/sonobuoy/issues/420

Change-Id: I613fab635b97a70ac20820e1ececde48952ac2da

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-08 13:45:28.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes a race condition in the hash ring code

The current hash ring code suffers from several problems:

1. The cache is reset on any get_topic_for call, which means that the
   cache is not used between API calls. Previously it was done to work
   around the situation when a new conductor is not visible until the API
   process restarts. Currently we refresh the hash rings periodically.

   This patch removes resetting the cache. To avoid waiting 2 minutes to
   be able to use a new driver:
   1) the hash ring cache is always rebuilt when a ring is not found,
   2) the hash_ring_reset_interval option was changed to 15 seconds.

2. The reset of the cache races with the hot path in the get_ring call.
   It is possible that the reset happens after the class-level cache
   variable is checked but before it is used, yielding None.

   This patch stores the value of the class-level variable to a local
   variable before checking, thus ensuring None is never returned.

Finally, some logging was added to the modified code to make this kind
of problems more debugable in the future.

Change-Id: I6e18c6ec23a053b59c76fcadd52b13d84d81b4fb
Story: #2003966
Task: #26896
Partial-Bug: #1792872
(cherry picked from commit 5471157e4fdb5a735a29d88f5ad3af0d4b765ea3)
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes a race condition in the hash ring code

The current hash ring code suffers from several problems:

1. The cache is reset on any get_topic_for call, which means that the
   cache is not used between API calls. Previously it was done to work
   around the situation when a new conductor is not visible until the API
   process restarts. Currently we refresh the hash rings periodically.

   This patch removes resetting the cache. To avoid waiting 2 minutes to
   be able to use a new driver:
   1) the hash ring cache is always rebuilt when a ring is not found,
   2) the hash_ring_reset_interval option was changed to 15 seconds.

2. The reset of the cache races with the hot path in the get_ring call.
   It is possible that the reset happens after the class-level cache
   variable is checked but before it is used, yielding None.

   This patch stores the value of the class-level variable to a local
   variable before checking, thus ensuring None is never returned.

Finally, some logging was added to the modified code to make this kind
of problems more debugable in the future.

Change-Id: I6e18c6ec23a053b59c76fcadd52b13d84d81b4fb
Story: #2003966
Task: #26896
Partial-Bug: #1792872
(cherry picked from commit 5471157e4fdb5a735a29d88f5ad3af0d4b765ea3)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-21 14:05:33.000000000', 'message': "sphinxext: Start parsing 'DocumentedRuleDefault.description' as rST

Users expect this to be parsed as rST and write their docstrings accordingly.
This has the potential to introduce warnings for users with improperly
formatted rST and these warnings can be promoted to errors if 'sphinx-build' is
used with the '-W' option. As a result, we disable the 'warning-is-error'
logger for these options. We may wish to change this behavior in the future.

It is not really possible to test this yet as the output wouldn't look much
different. In addition, the error messages generated are rather unhelpful. Both
of these can be changed in a future modification.

Change-Id: I4572eef31a8675eabb791c14279490348e949cd0
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
sphinxext: Start parsing 'DocumentedRuleDefault.description' as rST

Users expect this to be parsed as rST and write their docstrings accordingly.
This has the potential to introduce warnings for users with improperly
formatted rST and these warnings can be promoted to errors if 'sphinx-build' is
used with the '-W' option. As a result, we disable the 'warning-is-error'
logger for these options. We may wish to change this behavior in the future.

It is not really possible to test this yet as the output wouldn't look much
different. In addition, the error messages generated are rather unhelpful. Both
of these can be changed in a future modification.

Change-Id: I4572eef31a8675eabb791c14279490348e949cd0
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that

Change-Id: I0a2bb12f846b9cb42f96469ad731397fa929045c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I0a2bb12f846b9cb42f96469ad731397fa929045c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add SITE_BRANDING configuration option

Used to control the title of the web pages
that horizon renders. Default value is set
to undef which means this option will not be
added to the configuration file and the horizon
default will be used.

If specified it will add the SITE_BRANDING option
to the local_settings file.

Change-Id: I683341f4f948fb9d639a35ce81a66959fe699962

commit_message:
change the dist name to 'openstack-keystone'

We are updating all Python projects to publish artifacts to PyPI. The name
"keystone" is already taken there by another project, and they have not
responded our request to claim the name. We therefore need to change
the dist name used to package keystone. We have some other projects
publishing using an "openstack-" prefix, so I propose using the name
"openstack-keystone". This will not change the imports or anything else
about how the code works, just how it is packaged.

Change-Id: I8bbbe874a5eff3e001effa9eee44a44c61094568
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

This will test that the retries addition to the workspace setup role

role.

commit_message:
sphinxext: Handle multi-line group descriptions

While multi-line help texts for opts were already handled properly, the
same was not true of groups. Close this gap, allowing us to resolve the
FIXME in the process.

Change-Id: Ic564dbff983205134386ba5b7047d6d811c60ef1
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
sphinxext: Print output to logs, not to file

The functionality previously added here was broken as it did not include
a required newline. Rather than fix it, modify the whole thing to print
to logs instead of a temporary file. This should achieve the same effect
with less side effects.

Change-Id: I74d11a54d57d30aab7f97f4fcce9fee0b7d87cbc
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1782316

subject: Dissuade .gitignore references to personal tools
messages: [{'account_id': 9414, 'date': '2018-10-08 03:40:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-10-08 17:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-08 03:40:49.000000000', 'message': "Dissuade .gitignore references to personal tools

Developers run all sorts of different tools within Git repositories,
any of which can leave their own special trashfiles all over the
place. We can't every hope to catalog them all, so better to
recommend developers simply configure a global core.excludesfile to
filter the irrelevant files which tend to get created by their
personal choice of tools. Add a comment block explaining this, for
clarity, and remove the one current editor-specific entry present.

We can, and should of course, continue to list files created by the
tools recommended by our workflow (test frameworks, documentation
and packaging builds, et cetera).

This change is a port of Ib58a57267b064e4142686de6c37a70dbff04b9a7
from the openstack-dev/cookiecutter repository.

Change-Id: Ibdfd87dd41f746c65d9694560cd61586af22ad87
"}]
commit_message:
Dissuade .gitignore references to personal tools

Developers run all sorts of different tools within Git repositories,
any of which can leave their own special trashfiles all over the
place. We can't every hope to catalog them all, so better to
recommend developers simply configure a global core.excludesfile to
filter the irrelevant files which tend to get created by their
personal choice of tools. Add a comment block explaining this, for
clarity, and remove the one current editor-specific entry present.

We can, and should of course, continue to list files created by the
tools recommended by our workflow (test frameworks, documentation
and packaging builds, et cetera).

This change is a port of Ib58a57267b064e4142686de6c37a70dbff04b9a7
from the openstack-dev/cookiecutter repository.

Change-Id: Ibdfd87dd41f746c65d9694560cd61586af22ad87

commit_message:
Adds barbican to osclient

This patch is the foundation for adding Barnican based
scenarios. The browbeat project would like to measure the
performance of barbican keys, in order to do this we need
to add barbican support to rally-openstack.

Change-Id: If23299ade2580f5dc76a02cd5b29f94558356c67
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chucks@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add Magnum API WSGI support

Adds support for running the Magnum API under WSGI with Apache.

Change-Id: I6c564992218a0802981eece5bff8b2a4a7a85f7c
(cherry picked from commit e16f87c6ac48986debd40852067ef6f7272ddd28)

subject: Extend timeout to 3 hours
messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-10-05 08:52:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-10-05 08:56:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-10-06 21:55:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1\n\nI dunno if this is necessary, Bionic has clearly an issue because it takes 2 hours and 25 minutes (in this case at least), while OpenSUSE is entirely broken..'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-10-08 17:13:01.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-05 08:52:11.000000000', 'message': 'Extend timeout to 3 hours

We are getting a lot of timeout failures, often right at
the end of the test execution. While the reasons for this
are explored we extend the timeout to 3 hours to allow
development to continue.

Change-Id: I4e4bf03460f4a894f0f0b71e57ed7c45eb6bfb8e
'}]
commit_message:
Extend timeout to 3 hours

We are getting a lot of timeout failures, often right at
the end of the test execution. While the reasons for this
are explored we extend the timeout to 3 hours to allow
development to continue.

Change-Id: I4e4bf03460f4a894f0f0b71e57ed7c45eb6bfb8e

commit_message:
Dissuade .gitignore references to personal tools

Developers run all sorts of different tools within Git repositories,
any of which can leave their own special trashfiles all over the
place. We can't every hope to catalog them all, so better to
recommend developers simply configure a global core.excludesfile to
filter the irrelevant files which tend to get created by their
personal choice of tools. Add a comment block explaining this, for
clarity, and remove the one current editor-specific entry present.

We can, and should of course, continue to list files created by the
tools recommended by our workflow (test frameworks, documentation
and packaging builds, et cetera).

This change is a port of Ib58a57267b064e4142686de6c37a70dbff04b9a7
from the openstack-dev/cookiecutter repository.

Change-Id: I1f7836a00bedc408ecbdd11248a6d999c8d44f8a

subject: DNM testing set libvird selinux label virtd_t
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-08 14:19:21.000000000', 'message': 'DNM testing set libvird selinux label virtd_t

- The libvirtd package expect to run with the
  virtd_t selinux label.
- When deployed with tripleo in a container
  libvirtd has the container_share_t label
  applied to /usr/sbin/libvirtd.
- This change uses runcon to execute libvirtd
  under the correct selinux label.

Change-Id: I6c2cd50b4a102cf3c82aa5851aa61048da66aa0f
'}]
commit_message:
DNM testing set libvird selinux label virtd_t

- The libvirtd package expect to run with the
  virtd_t selinux label.
- When deployed with tripleo in a container
  libvirtd has the container_share_t label
  applied to /usr/sbin/libvirtd.
- This change uses runcon to execute libvirtd
  under the correct selinux label.

Change-Id: I6c2cd50b4a102cf3c82aa5851aa61048da66aa0f

subject: Dissuade .gitignore references to personal tools
messages:
[{'account_id': 9414, 'date': '2018-10-08 03:40:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-10-08 10:35:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Please don't do this. These changes are totally unnecessary and benefit no-one in any particular way."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-10-08 16:46:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Agreed, I patched the various cookiecutter repos so that we don't continue to propagate the idea that people should be tweaking .gitignore files constantly for everyone's favorite dev tools and utilities. The idea was to help avoid people unnecessarily patching these files, not to encourage yet one more rash of pointless code copying to every imaginable repository."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-10-08 16:57:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

subject: Add os-log-merger to governance
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 6928, 'name': 'Ben Nemec', 'email': 'openstack@nemebean.com', 'username': 'bnemec'}, {'_account_id': 8788, 'name': 'Miguel Angel Ajo', 'email': 'mangelajo@redhat.com', 'username': 'mangelajo'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23078, 'name': 'Jeremy Freudberg', 'email': 'jeremyfreudberg@gmail.com', 'username': 'jeremyfreudberg'}, {'_account_id': 23804, 'name': 'Daniel Alvarez', 'email': 'dalvarez@redhat.com', 'username': 'dalvarez'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-10-02 10:06:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-10-02 11:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-10-02 13:04:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-10-02 13:05:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-02 13:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-02 14:46:04.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-10-02 15:11:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-10-02 15:34:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Note: I accept suggestions for a more catchy name, I'm not good at that..."}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2018-10-03 08:38:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-10-03 13:38:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-03 16:16:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So... a question that is inevitably going to asked is whether this needs to be a standalone thing with PTL elections and all the other requirements of a top-level OpenStack project, or if it could just live under e.g. Oslo (which is already responsible for the logging output).

Have you spoken to the Oslo team about this? It may be that they don't want it, but I don't think we can reach a decision without that conversation happening."}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-10-03 17:41:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm very out of the loop on all this, but is there any sense in a common home for os-log-merger and osprofiler? As in, a new top-level Tracing project?

Also, my naive instinct is that this isn't quite right for oslo, as it's not a library. But again, I'm just speculating as I don't have the proper intimate knowledge."}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-10-04 13:57:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks Zane, I guess talking to the oslo team could be an option, I didn't do it for the fact that it's not a library.  If you believe there's room to make it an oslo deliberable, I'd be fine with that.

Jeremy, this is different to osprofiler.

This is for post-mortem analysis of logs, when we only have the logs (typical case for the gate, and also for customers), osprofiler needs you to configure and prepare your profiling session for, profiling (and tracing)"}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-10-04 13:59:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

let's keep it on wait until I talk to Ben Nemec (Oslo PTL)"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-08 16:03:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The Oslo team discussed this in our meeting today and suggested that Miguel look into forming a SIG with some of the folks working on other operator-focused tools like this. http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/oslo/2018/oslo.2018-10-08-15.00.log.html'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-10-08 16:59:02.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

looking into forming an Op Tools SIG'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-02 10:06:44.000000000', 'message': 'Add os-log-merger to governance

The mission of this project is to provide a set of tools for log
aggregation and debugging in the context of OpenStack, making
administration and development easier when debugging
multi node and multi service traces.

Depends-On: I987006060aca3f215909051964feeedaa6b88d84
Change-Id: I37b3a2f93222fbbcb0fa1e6a6f18c6099dcca110
'}, {'created': '2018-10-02 13:04:41.000000000', 'message': 'Add os-log-merger to governance

The mission of this project is to provide a set of tools for log
aggregation and debugging in the context of OpenStack, making
administration and development easier when debugging
multi node and multi service traces.

Depends-On: I987006060aca3f215909051964feeedaa6b88d84
Change-Id: I37b3a2f93222fbbcb0fa1e6a6f18c6099dcca110
'}]
commit_message:
Add os-log-merger to governance

The mission of this project is to provide a set of tools for log
aggregation and debugging in the context of OpenStack, making
administration and development easier when debugging
multi node and multi service traces.

Depends-On: I987006060aca3f215909051964feeedaa6b88d84
Change-Id: I37b3a2f93222fbbcb0fa1e6a6f18c6099dcca110

commit_message:
Dissuade .gitignore references to personal tools

Developers run all sorts of different tools within Git repositories,
any of which can leave their own special trashfiles all over the
place. We can't every hope to catalog them all, so better to
recommend developers simply configure a global core.excludesfile to
filter the irrelevant files which tend to get created by their
personal choice of tools. Add a comment block explaining this, for
clarity, and remove the one current editor-specific entry present.

We can, and should of course, continue to list files created by the
tools recommended by our workflow (test frameworks, documentation
and packaging builds, et cetera).

This change is a port of Ib58a57267b064e4142686de6c37a70dbff04b9a7
from the openstack-dev/cookiecutter repository.

Change-Id: Ieec55ee15dbb72ebee396619cb51d4a7baccf4b2

[{'created': '2018-10-05 17:00:17.000000000', 'message': "/tmp with noexec fix

Closes-Bug: #1796220

commit_message:
/tmp with noexec fix

Adds option to specify tmp folder prefix and also defines a
default tmp folder outside of /tmp.

There's also a new validation that makes sure that scripts
are executable.

Change-Id: I041402eff9443c2dd4b2e44b0bc3ec2acccb7171
Closes-Bug: #1796220

subject: Separate the thread pool for health and stats update
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6469, 'name': 'Carlos Gonçalves', 'display_name': 'Carlos Goncalves', 'email': 'cgoncalves@redhat.com', 'username': 'cgoncalves'}, {'_account_id': 6579, 'name': 'Nir Magnezi', 'email': 'nmagnezi@redhat.com', 'username': 'nmagnezi'}, {'_account_id': 10273, 'name': 'Adam Harwell', 'email': 'flux.adam@gmail.com', 'username': 'rm_you'}, {'_account_id': 10850, 'name': 'German Eichberger', 'email': 'german.eichberger@gmail.com', 'username': 'german'}, {'_account_id': 11628, 'name': 'Michael Johnson', 'email': 'johnsomor@gmail.com', 'username': 'johnsom'}, {'_account_id': 11884, 'name': 'Masaki Kanno', 'email': 'kanno.masaki@jp.fujitsu.com', 'username': 'Kanno'}, {'_account_id': 13702, 'name': 'yushiro', 'username': 'yushiro', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 15309, 'name': 'zhaobo', 'email': 'bzhaojyathousandy@gmail.com', 'username': 'ZhaoBo'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26299, 'name': 'Tatsuma Matsuki', 'email': 'matsuki.tatsuma@jp.fujitsu.com', 'username': 'tatsuma'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 26299, 'date': '2018-07-11 06:34:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26299, 'date': '2018-07-11 09:11:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26299, 'date': '2018-07-11 11:09:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11884, 'date': '2018-07-26 08:05:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13702, 'date': '2018-07-26 10:04:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-07-26 16:15:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-07-26 16:16:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-07-27 08:38:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Splitting out health and stats updates sounds good. However, stats updates is still a blocking operation as the RPCClient used by the event queue streamer keeps retrying to send the message indefinitely. So, this would be fine if we had up to status_update_threads to process. Any new stats message that would come in would be dropped because there are no more workers available. Later, once the messaging transport comes back online, the consumer (neutron-lbaas in this case) would receive the oldest stats messages. To fix this, we can set RPCClient with a retry. Perhaps retry=0 (no retry is attempted) or a low number would be a good.

https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.messaging/latest/reference/rpcclient.html

https://github.com/openstack/octavia/blob/d3092c0facdbd4e3d0c0190710e286914ee14006/octavia/controller/queue/event_queue.py#L72

Also, note that if retry=0 is set we could even eventually drop the existing patch as is today. But I like the idea of separating health and stats update :-)'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-07-27 16:21:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Yeah, I like this patch and splitting the thread pools.'}, {'account_id': 26299, 'date': '2018-07-30 03:15:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Thank you many comments. I'm preparing a updated patch to rename parameter names.

I understand the need to set RPCClient retry to be limited number and that is a good option to fix this issue. But, I want to focus on splitting thread pool on this patch because I don't check the actual impact to set the limited number of retries and drop health update messages. (Dropping stats update message seems OK.)"}, {'account_id': 26299, 'date': '2018-08-07 07:19:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-08-07 08:31:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Thanks for addressing reviewers' comments!
Octavia is tagged as an assert:follows-standard-deprecation project, we need follow deprecation requirements."}, {'account_id': 13702, 'date': '2018-08-07 12:05:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Some nits.'}, {'account_id': 26299, 'date': '2018-08-08 02:08:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 13702, 'date': '2018-08-08 05:48:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11884, 'date': '2018-08-15 10:54:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-08-20 09:26:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Looks better now, thank you!

A minor note that may be worth a new patch set as I would like to have this patch backported to rocky and queens.'}, {'account_id': 26299, 'date': '2018-08-22 00:13:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 26299, 'date': '2018-08-22 02:13:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Thank you. I updated the comment to be removed in or after "T" release.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-08-22 07:21:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

LGTM, thank you. Performance of the Health Manager is an important topic with known caveats. This patch should ease a little the pain some have been experiencing.

I would like to see this patch backported to stable versions. The question is if we can do it without going against the stable branch policy (see https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#review-guidelines).'}, {'account_id': 11884, 'date': '2018-08-22 10:23:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 13702, 'date': '2018-08-23 01:56:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 15309, 'date': '2018-08-23 02:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-09-16 15:28:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

LGTM. AS per my earlier comment, we will have to check how to best backport this not to go against stable branch policy.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-10-01 18:01:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-10-01 19:44:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/rocky as commit d54a96e18cba73ab71825fa0479d470590d98253'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-08 16:29:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-08 16:40:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-11 06:34:51.000000000', 'message': 'Separate the thread pool for health and stats update.

When queue_event_streamer driver is used and RabbitMQ
is down, stats update processes occupy the thread pool
which is shared with health update processes. Then,
RabbitMQ down unexpectedly leads to delete all existing
amphorae. This commit separates the thread pool and aims
to keep the existing amphorae working even when RabbitMQ
is down.

Change-Id: I576687f5b646496ff3a00787cf5e8c27f36b9448
Task: 22929
Story: 2002937
'}, {'created': '2018-07-11 09:11:17.000000000', 'message': 'Separate the thread pool for health and stats update.

is down, stats update processes occupy the thread pool

amphorae. This commit separates the thread pool and aims
to keep the existing amphorae working even when RabbitMQ
is down.

Task: 22929

commit_message:
Separate the thread pool for health and stats update

When queue_event_streamer driver is used and RabbitMQ
is down, stats update processes occupy the thread pool
which is shared with health update processes. Then,
RabbitMQ down unexpectedly leads to delete all existing
amphorae. This commit separates the thread pool and aims
to keep the existing amphorae working even when RabbitMQ
is down.

Change-Id: I576687f5b646496ff3a00787cf5e8c27f36b9448
Task: 22929
Story: 2002937

commit_message:
Added volume usage collection, when cinder_ceilometer_enabled

In order to get volume metrics sended to ceilometer,
cinder-volume-usage-audit must be manually runned (or with cron/systemd timer).
Similar to nova approach (volume_usage_audit_period in cinder.conf)
is not working.

So this change add cinder_volume_usage_audit variable,
according to which cron job will be placed
on cinder-volumes servers.

Job uses another type of quotes, due to escaping problems

Change-Id: Iaf021f7776a73a68676d762cb84518b0db412ddd

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-08 00:39:15.000000000', 'message': "Ignore spurious nested stack locks in convergence

Several operations (e.g. stack check) are yet to be converted to
convergence-style workflows, and still create locks. While we try to always
remove dead locks, it's possible that if one of these gets left behind we
won't notice, since convergence doesn't actually use stack locks for most
regular operations.

When doing _check_status_complete() on a nested stack resource, we wait for
the operation to release the nested stack's lock before reporting the
resource completed, to ensure that for legacy operations the nested stack
is ready to perform another action on as soon as the resource is complete.
For convergence stacks this is an unnecessary DB call, and it can lead to
resources never completing if a stray lock happens to be left in the
database.

Only check the nested stack's stack lock for operations where we are not
taking a resource lock. This corresponds exactly to legacy-style
operations.

This is modified from master to inline the _should_lock_on_action()
method, which does not exist on this branch.

Change-Id: I4eb20ad82cc3e9434da34500fafa3880567d0959
Story: #1727142
Task: 24939
(cherry picked from commit 83ae156927f879af59d7db518f888280ef369428)
"}]
commit_message:
Ignore spurious nested stack locks in convergence

Several operations (e.g. stack check) are yet to be converted to
convergence-style workflows, and still create locks. While we try to always
remove dead locks, it's possible that if one of these gets left behind we
won't notice, since convergence doesn't actually use stack locks for most
regular operations.

When doing _check_status_complete() on a nested stack resource, we wait for
the operation to release the nested stack's lock before reporting the
resource completed, to ensure that for legacy operations the nested stack
is ready to perform another action on as soon as the resource is complete.
For convergence stacks this is an unnecessary DB call, and it can lead to
resources never completing if a stray lock happens to be left in the
database.

Only check the nested stack's stack lock for operations where we are not
taking a resource lock. This corresponds exactly to legacy-style
operations.

This is modified from master to inline the _should_lock_on_action()
method, which does not exist on this branch.

Change-Id: I4eb20ad82cc3e9434da34500fafa3880567d0959
Story: #1727142
Task: 24939
(cherry picked from commit 83ae156927f879af59d7db518f888280ef369428)

support configuring the TLS proxy.

commit_message:
ironic: enable noop management interface by default

Some hardware messes up boot order on IPMI bootdev command. To work
around it we introduced a 'noop' management interface, that expects
the boot order to be fully preconfigured. This change enables it
in the overcloud by default.

Change-Id: I74620233e5af58a02e3e47da08dff7148e2ef10d
Story: #2003203

commit_message:
/tmp with noexec fix

Adds option to specify tmp folder prefix and also defines a
default tmp folder outside of /tmp.

There's also a new validation that makes sure that scripts
are executable.

Change-Id: If5946af7f6b009cb3539c783cf82701d3e848f35
Closes-Bug: #1796220

commit_message:
Propose a new release 1.3.0

Also, this patch updates upper-constraints and fixes failed tests which
started failing due to incompatible change in Rally framework

subject: Fix IPA image download
messages:
[{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-08-29 12:14:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28048, 'date': '2018-08-29 14:10:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Might be nice if you could specify the checksum in kayobe config. You would then fail if, for example, `ipa_kernel_upstream_url` was changed to file with a different checksum. This would serve as a reminder to update your kayobe config with a new checksum. Might make it easier to audit when the file has changed - otherwise you could have the situation where no change to kayobe config was made, but the ipa image would still be rebuilt.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-08-29 17:40:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Might be nice if you could specify the checksum in kayobe config.
 > You would then fail if, for example, `ipa_kernel_upstream_url` was
 > changed to file with a different checksum. This would serve as a
 > reminder to update your kayobe config with a new checksum. Might
 > make it easier to audit when the file has changed - otherwise you
 > could have the situation where no change to kayobe config was made,
 > but the ipa image would still be rebuilt.

This is a fair point. I went with this approach because:

* It's what bifrost does, so we can pass the config straight through
* The upstream IPA images have checksum files available
* You could update the IPA image without modifying kayobe-config

I realise the last point is the opposite to what you're saying :) It does mean we can have a default config that we don't have to keep updating (except for release name changes), and won't go stale.

You can get more fine grained control over the images in this scheme by using immutable image URLs, with a different unique URL each time an image is built. It's not quite as good a guarantee as a checksum, but it's probably similar to referencing a docker image by tag, a package by version, or a git repo by branch/tag.

WDYT?"}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-08-29 17:51:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 28048, 'date': '2018-08-30 08:34:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Fair enough.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-10-02 12:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 16984, 'date': '2018-10-08 14:37:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-29 12:14:06.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Fix IPA image download

The IPA ramdisk and kernel images may be built or downloaded via a URL.
If the latter option is used, any images previously downloaded to
$KOLLA_CONFIG_PATH/config/ironic/ironic-agent.* would previously not be
updated if the image contents change.

This change introduces variables for setting a URL to a file containing
checksums for the images. The algorithm used to compute the checksum is
also configurable (default sha256). This allows us to ensure we are
using the correct version of the image, while avoiding an expensive few
hundred megabyte image download just to check.

If a checksum is not specified, the image will be downloaded every time
to ensure that it is up to date.

Change-Id: I8120518ed98d61f3652f5205ce7ec9f798ab2aa1
Story: 2001660
Task: 6693

commit_message:
Fix IPA image download

The IPA ramdisk and kernel images may be built or downloaded via a URL.
If the latter option is used, any images previously downloaded to
$KOLLA_CONFIG_PATH/config/ironic/ironic-agent.* would previously not be
updated if the image contents change.

This change introduces variables for setting a URL to a file containing
checksums for the images. The algorithm used to compute the checksum is
also configurable (default sha256). This allows us to ensure we are
using the correct version of the image, while avoiding an expensive few
hundred megabyte image download just to check.

If a checksum is not specified, the image will be downloaded every time
to ensure that it is up to date.

Change-Id: I8120518ed98d61f3652f5205ce7ec9f798ab2aa1
Story: 2001660
Task: 6693

commit_message:
[Experimental] Unit Test Mistral Workflows

Some open questions:
  - A bunch of internal imports (more than I hoped)
  - We need mistral as a test requirement - it isn't in global requirements
  - sqlite only so far (possibly a good thing)
  - We need to manually register every action we use - unless it is a tripleo
    action, then it is added automatically thanks to setup.cfg, but we need to
    mock it. Re-registering a new action may be easier than mocking, if that
    works
  - Tests are heavily tied to Mistral internals and database. We should
    probably write a bunch of helper methods to abstract anything we access
    should it change later. I'd hope only one file would ever import from
    Mistral directly.
  - We *might* need to run these in their own dedicated test suite. There
    seems to be an issue where it is causing other tripleo-common tests to
    hang. Due to eventlet monkey patching maybe?

Implements: blueprint workflows-unit-testing
Change-Id: Id8600ee193531f283aa14c611309fea4d15df259

commit_message:
Add initial workflow tests for the stack.yaml workbook

This test is intentionally simple to help test the general framework
setup. It tests the tripleo.stack.v1.wait_for_stack_does_not_exist
workflow which should always be succesful as no Heat stack is ever
created.

Change-Id: Ie3809077a3b09efe6768569a37c12ffb42b57b2b

commit_message:
Introduce alternative to get ip_addresses and server_names

This introduces a key called "base_service_name" which you can set in
order to use the "magically" generated <service name>_node_ips and
<service name>_node_names, which will set ip_addresses and server_names
in the HAProxy endpoint. This makes it easier for folks creating
services to add custom HAProxy endpoints.

Change-Id: I5de14152904d06c49e9d5b2df6e3f09a35f23d92

In addition, this change seems good for many environments since the explanation of this conversation."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-10-08 10:56:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

commit_message:
Set defult value of num_nvme_discover_tries=5

Discovering newly connected devices in the initiator side can be slow
when there are old connections, increasing the retries is important
to discover the new connected device.

Change-Id: I62a8162bf96d51f7252cfefbffc1a46010a3a612
Closes-Bug: #1792313

subject: Mapped Groups don't exist breaks WebSSO
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2903, 'name': 'Morgan Fainberg', 'email': 'morgan.fainberg@gmail.com', 'username': 'mdrnstm'}, {'_account_id': 5046, 'name': 'Lance Bragstad', 'email': 'lbragstad@redhat.com', 'username': 'ldbragst'}, {'_account_id': 8116, 'name': 'John Dennis', 'email': 'jdennis@redhat.com', 'username': 'jdennis'}, {'_account_id': 8482, 'name': 'Colleen Murphy', 'email': 'colleen@gazlene.net', 'username': 'krinkle'}, {'_account_id': 8866, 'name': 'Raildo Mascena de Sousa Filho', 'email': 'rmascena@redhat.com', 'username': 'raildo'}, {'_account_id': 16465, 'name': 'Kristi Nikolla', 'email': 'knikolla@bu.edu', 'username': 'knikolla'}, {'_account_id': 20444, 'name': 'gh159m', 'email': 'gh159m@att.com', 'username': 'gh159m'}, {'_account_id': 21420, 'name': 'Gage Hugo', 'email': 'gagehugo@gmail.com', 'username': 'ghugo'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 27621, 'name': 'Vishakha Agarwal', 'email': 'agarwalvishakha18@gmail.com', 'username': 'Vishakha'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-08-30 05:45:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-08-30 10:32:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-08-30 10:34:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8866, 'date': '2018-09-03 12:05:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hey Vishakha, 
looks like the issue here is that the websso it not dealing with this exception properly. Is there a why this exception is not handled in the UI side? Also, I saw that MappedGroupNotFound is inherited by UnexpectedError which raises the 500 https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/d80442af2b7771faf7b3146da0025dc38f49eadd/keystone/exception.py#L565, maybe would be better raise a NotFound exception, since it will fit better in case.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-09-06 13:01:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Vishakha can you respond to Raildo's question?"}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-09-06 16:47:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Hey Vishakha,
 > looks like the issue here is that the websso it not dealing with
 > this exception properly. Is there a why this exception is not
 > handled in the UI side? Also, I saw that MappedGroupNotFound is
 > inherited by UnexpectedError which raises the 500 https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/d80442af2b7771faf7b3146da0025dc38f49eadd/keystone/exception.py#L565,
 > maybe would be better raise a NotFound exception, since it will fit
 > better in case.

Hi Raildo. Thanks for the comment. I think any exception raised will break the WebSSO whether internalservererror or notfound error. So I preferred replacing it with a simple log.
Kindly correct if wrong. Thanks'}, {'account_id': 8116, 'date': '2018-09-06 21:05:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Overall the patch seems fine but I'm concerned about one aspect I'd like a clarification on and I'll address Raildo's question.

The original patch in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/162788 introduced a new unit test test_lists_with_missing_group_in_backend() to validate the fix. I'm wondering why that unit test did not catch the regression. I haven't spent enough time looking through the code to understand why the test continued to pass after the regression but I think we need to understand why that test didn't catch the regression. We may need to address that. Once we have an explanation I'm happy to remove my -1.

As for Raildo's question, websso can't deal with this, at least not via exceptions. The loop where the exception is raised must complete otherwise you won't get a list of group id's. Also the inability to obtain a group id has already been determined to be acceptable in federation, that's the problem we're trying to fix. The federation code does not care, nor should it, that a group is unknown UNLESS the group is referenced in the mapping rules. I'm pretty sure that case is covered but I'll admit I haven't double checked that all groups appearing in the mapping are present. Logging the missing group at the DEBUG level seems like the right approach."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-09-13 15:23:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-09-13 15:25:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

re-reading jdennis's comment, we might need to not raise the exception. lets make sure we address his -1 concern(s)"}, {'account_id': 8866, 'date': '2018-09-18 19:35:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

So, looking into the master code looks like some asserts were removed in the test_lists_with_missing_group_in_backend(), this is probably the reason why we didn't catch this bug earlier. Should we add again these asserts described in the original patch:  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/162788?"}, {'account_id': 8116, 'date': '2018-09-19 03:04:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I agree with you Raildo, this block of code in test_lists_with_missing_group_in_backend()

+        r = self._issue_unscoped_token(assertion='UNMATCHED_GROUP_ASSERTION')
+        assigned_group_ids = r.json['token']['user']['OS-FEDERATION']['groups']
+        self.assertEqual(1, len(assigned_group_ids))
+        self.assertEqual(group['id'], assigned_group_ids[0]['id'])

seems to have disappeared, without it the test is a no-op.

I noticed this when I looked at this a week or two ago. At that time I tried to figure out which commit removed them and I couldn't find the commit using

git log -p -SUNMATCHED_GROUP_ASSERTION

and was perplexed but pushed it off on this commit's author to resolve. I can't explain the missing code, could it have been a bad merge? Tomorrow I'll try and do a bisect and see if I can find the commit where the lines disappeared.

I also want to address Morgan's comment, but I'll do that tomorrow as well."}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-09-20 00:03:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi all. Thanks for the review. Should I add the missing asserts in the patch??'}, {'account_id': 8116, 'date': '2018-09-20 16:57:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

I've tested after restoring the missing lines in the unit test. Without modifying the raising of the MappedGroupNotFound exception the unit test test_lists_with_missing_group_in_backend() fails as expected. After adding in the change to replace MappedGroupNotFound exception with a debug message the test passes. So yes, you should restore these missing lines to the end of test_lists_with_missing_group_in_backend()

        r = self._issue_unscoped_token(assertion='UNMATCHED_GROUP_ASSERTION')
        assigned_group_ids = r.json['token']['user']['OS-FEDERATION']['groups']
        self.assertEqual(1, len(assigned_group_ids))
        self.assertEqual(group['id'], assigned_group_ids[0]['id'])

As to how these lines were removed, it's something I'm still working on. Using git bisect I found the commit after which the lines were missing. What I don't understand yet is the commit does not show those lines being removed. I'm very concerned that our source tree was apparently modified unintentionally and I want to understand how that happened. After a lot of investigation I'm starting to believe some of the confusion in regards to the git history is from viewing the commit logs using git's default chronological history instead of what git calls topographic  history, I'm pursing that at the moment.

I also what to address Morgan's earlier comment that a 401 Unauthorized error should be returned and that unknown groups are bogus and indicative of poor configuration. I don't believe that is true. I believe in prior discussions everyone was in agreement that IdP's can and will include group names that are unknown to Keystone and this is not an error. In addition this is not unique to Keycloak, any IdP may behave this way, it's not a configuration error. However, I do see value in knowing which group names failed to match because one of them might be mandatory and if a mandatory group failed to map it should be an error. But at the moment we have no mechanism to check that condition so the best we can do is ignore unknown groups and hope the missing (mandatory) group problem will be picked up elsewhere, which can then be backtracked to the federation mapping. But that is an RFE or possibly another bug, however this should not stop this commit from going forward."}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-09-21 02:28:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-09-21 02:32:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi John. According to your comment I appended the missing lines in the test. Pl find the new patch set.'}, {'account_id': 8116, 'date': '2018-09-21 02:36:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I went through the logs in first-parent order and reviewed the commit history in gitk and I can't find any commit that would have removed the missing lines. I can't invest any more time in this. The only possible explanation I can think of is that the merge had conflicts and the conflicts were resolved manually but inadvertently removed the missing lines. The missing lines are very close if not identical to another commit so it wouldn't surprise me if during a merge conflict resolution they were omitted by accident. But does gerrit even permit manual conflict resolution? I've never had to do that in gerrit.

Anyway, provided the lines are restored I'll give the commit a +1 and move on."}, {'account_id': 8116, 'date': '2018-09-21 02:41:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Patchset #4 only has the missing lines restored, what happened to the other fixes? They are still needed.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-09-21 02:52:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-09-21 02:54:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-09-21 02:57:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-09-21 02:59:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> Patchset #4 only has the missing lines restored, what happened to
 > the other fixes? They are still needed.

Sorry John for the bad code merge. Updated the patch. Thanks'}, {'account_id': 8866, 'date': '2018-09-21 12:23:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 8116, 'date': '2018-09-21 14:06:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

Thank you Vishakha! Looks good to me now.'}, {'account_id': 16465, 'date': '2018-09-21 15:09:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

Looks good to me. Quick question before I +2. With this patch, the behavior becomes so that when a mapping specifies a group_name that doesn't exist, we log a DEBUG. When the mapping specified a group_id and it doesn't exist, we raise an exception. Is this the expected behavior from an administrator perspective or is the inconsistency confusing?"}, {'account_id': 8116, 'date': '2018-09-21 15:21:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: -Code-Review

That is an excellent question Kristi, I picked up on that as well but convinced myself it was OK. Here is my thinking:

IdP's uses group names, not openstack id's (in theory an IdP could be configured to send a an openstack group id but it would be poor practice to closely link identity information in the IdP to internal OpenStack per deployment data so I don't think we should worry about supporting it). That means the only way a group id can get into the checking logic is if it's hardcoded into the mapping rules. That is not unreasonable because the mapping rules are intimately tied to the OpenStack deployment and hence the internal id's. Still it's not a great idea, but not unreasonable. My feeling is if someone does embed group id's into the mapping rules then they have obligated themselves to using valid id's. If they screw up and use a bad id then throwing an exception rather than logging a debug message seems entirely correct."}, {'account_id': 16465, 'date': '2018-09-21 15:35:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

That was my feeling as well, wanted to double check first that it was intended behavior rather than an unthought of side effect. I would like to eventually see our docs updated to include these kind of best practices and mistakes, but that is a thought for another day.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2018-09-21 18:35:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 8866, 'date': '2018-09-24 16:06:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/rocky as commit 6bc81fec24f20da677c9979fcf380c777894df31'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-10-08 13:57:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}]

commit_message:
Mapped Groups don't exist breaks WebSSO

The issue occurs if a user has a group that
does not map to a project in OpenStack. At
which point an exception is raised and the
websso login blows up with a 500 message.
This is because of the exception being raised
when the group name not matches thus replacing
that with a log.

Change-Id: Ia7321705db118af28f3dc6e01d5b18e8650aa633
Closes-Bug: #1789450

commit_message:
api-ref: Move the evacuate action to admin action

The evacuate action can be performed by administrators only by default.
But there is the description of the evacuate action in
the "Servers - run an action (servers, action)" section.

It should be in the "Servers - run an administrative action
(servers, action)" section.
So move to the description of the evacuate action
into the administrative action section.

Change-Id: Iafdd77c14c702af24dbb3f5a3adecc45b3014c48
Closes-Bug: #1796054

subject: generate-constraints: Fix error handling in Python3
messages: [{'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-04 20:10:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-10-06 20:24:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2018-10-08 10:40:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-04 20:10:21.000000000', 'message': 'generate-constraints: Fix error handling in Python3

When handling an error, we were trying to combine data from the output
of multiple commands, some of which had already been converted to
strings (from bytes) and some of which had not. This is forbidden in
Python 3. (We were also trying to decode UTF-8 multiple times as a
result.)

Store all of the output as bytes, and decode if and when it is needed.

Change-Id: I35cd872f7bb38be1006bd6bf8dc910a1b52aadeb
'}]
commit_message:
generate-constraints: Fix error handling in Python3

When handling an error, we were trying to combine data from the output
of multiple commands, some of which had already been converted to
strings (from bytes) and some of which had not. This is forbidden in
Python 3. (We were also trying to decode UTF-8 multiple times as a
result.)

Store all of the output as bytes, and decode if and when it is needed.

Change-Id: I35cd872f7bb38be1006bd6bf8dc910a1b52aadeb

subject: Add new config option cinder-backup-panel-role
messages:
[{'account_id': 5112, 'date': '2018-08-21 13:02:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5112, 'date': '2018-08-21 13:48:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5112, 'date': '2018-08-27 08:01:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2018-09-26 08:25:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2018-09-26 08:26:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

resolved merge conflict'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2018-09-26 11:13:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Couple of comments;

Firstly I think the commit message should provide more information about what exactly we are doing here and how we are doing it i.e. injecting a non-standard policy rule "none".

Secondly, I believe that this should really be fixed in openstack-dashboard itself i.e. if backend_enabled is False the dashboard should exclude the backup panel altogether. However, since this would be unlikley to be backported due it likely being considered a feature and since the code this depends on has apparently recently changed, I would like to suggest an alternative:

Instead of setting the policy to "none" which i don't believe is an expected policy setting and could potentially have unexpected results, we could simply allow the operator to tell the charm what policy it wants to all the dashboard to use for obtaining information about backups (i.e. displaying the backups panel). That way if the operator wants to disable the panel for everybody they can specify a role name that doesn't exist and then if later they decide they want to use it for some users they can create that role and assign it to some users.'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2018-09-26 12:22:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2018-09-26 14:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2018-09-26 14:14:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2018-09-26 14:15:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5112, 'date': '2018-10-01 01:22:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2018-10-08 13:39:30.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Hi Seyeong, I think we can abandon this patch now since it is fixed in horizon upstream. The patch has been released to Stein and stable/rocky and will hopefully hit queens and pike so we can focus on the SRU instead. If you think we still need a charm patch let me know and we can discuss and reopen if necessary.'}]

commit_message:
Add new config option cinder-backup-panel-role

Currently horizon will display the backups panel regardless of
whether or not cinder-backup is set to True or False. While the
panel is view-only (the create backup cmd will be removed from
volumes in the volumes panel) some people might not want it
there at all so this new config opt allows defining a role e.g.
"cinder_backup_panel_viewer" and changing the default of
"rule:admin_or_owner" to "role:cinder_backup_panel_viewer" so
that the operator can either block everyone from seeing the panel
or add it selectively.

Change-Id: I2407f8fd4de73cddb0c8e542f271cccd76fcc169
Closes-bug: #1778771

commit_message:
stable-only: fix typo in IVS related privsep method

 - as part of this change [1], methods requiring root access for
   IVS  were moved to a separate file
 - there was a typo that causes failure to plug VM interface
 - this fixes the typo and includes the original file existence
   check to the utility method

This is a stable-only change for Queens because the code in
question was removed in Rocky [2].

[1] Ic48087fdf283b3ba503294a944be91be0c338132
[2] Icf948f6ee1c0da2327fb5eac61fec6e89ac30531

commit_message:
Use tox-docs for building

Switch docs to new PTI docs interface using tox-docs via
the template build-openstack-docs-pti.

Fix tox.ini to use proper output directory.

With this change, Zuul now uses "tox -e docs" for building
documentation following the updated PTI.

Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/608443
Change-Id: Ifdb23c28a0c8a42542919dd02d8f459af324deec

Sphinx 1.5 and later allows a :reversed: parameter for :glob:
toctrees. Since we're presenting our resolution index in reverse
chronological order grouped by year, reversing the glob order keeps
the dates within each year consistently ordered as well. Yes, this

commit_message:
Reverse sort order for resolution date globs

Sphinx 1.5 and later allows a :reversed: parameter for :glob:
toctrees. Since we're presenting our resolution index in reverse
chronological order grouped by year, reversing the glob order keeps
the dates within each year consistently ordered as well. Yes, this
is probably me being OCD.

The SIGs governance resolution file was inconsistently named,
leading to it showing up outside the expected sort order. Rename the
file and add a permanent redirect from the old URL to the new one.

Related cleanup, the main index toctree was incorrectly marked as a
:glob: even though it didn't use any wildcard patterns so has been
corrected.

Change-Id: Ifbc6db87e41f01311b430080b97154d01708a2d4

subject: add Mohammed Naser as vice chair
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5263, 'name': 'Jeremy Stanley', 'display_name': 'fungi', 'email': 'fungi@yuggoth.org', 'username': 'fungi', 'status': 'missing, presumed fed'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-03 15:32:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-03 15:35:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

Not against Mohammed as the vice chair, but I there was some discussion about chair rotation and the vice chair being in line to become the actual chair in the next cycle. We should discuss that first and see if we want to do that before confirming this as if that is the case, we would want the vice chair to be nominated by the exising TC, and the person being nominated would need to be someone that will have a term that will extend through the next overlap in order to become chair.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-03 17:53:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Not against Mohammed as the vice chair, but I there was some
 > discussion about chair rotation and the vice chair being in line to
 > become the actual chair in the next cycle. We should discuss that
 > first and see if we want to do that before confirming this as if
 > that is the case, we would want the vice chair to be nominated by
 > the exising TC, and the person being nominated would need to be
 > someone that will have a term that will extend through the next
 > overlap in order to become chair.

We can certainly talk about that, although I don't particularly like the idea of forcing a rotation for the same reason I don't like term limits in general -- they force you into a change regardless of whether change makes sense.

I will be completely out of touch from 13 Oct through 28 Oct, so we should have someone in the vice chair role before then."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-04 13:31:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Rollcall-Vote

Removing my -1 so we can make sure there is coverage while Doug is out, but I think we need to discuss this more for future consideration.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-10-04 13:34:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

The commitment to be vice-chair is also completely different from the chair role. It's one thing to learn the rules and be available to replace the chair in case of PTO, it's another to agree to take the driver seat for 95% of the time...

Those are not honorary roles or interchangeable roles."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-10-04 14:53:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

As Thierry mentioned, the chair is still the lead on everything.  This is more of a continuity perspective so we can continue our 'normal' operations should the chair become unavailable, in terms of handling things merging into governance, however, by no means a replacement to the actual chair."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-04 15:18:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

Since Doug was just re-elected for a further year, any decision we make on forced rotation (which I'm against btw) doesn't need to take effect until after the next election."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-04 15:40:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-10-04 15:44:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-10-04 15:47:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

Thanks mnaser.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-04 16:14:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

We have the minimum number of positive votes on this to approve it 2018-10-08'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-08 13:08:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
etcd3: Allow for multi-host deployments

This reverts the accidental revert of 19279b0f8 that was introduced in
146332e34. Without this, it's not possible to start the devstack@etcd
service on hosts other than SERVICE_HOST for the reasons illustrated in
the original commit.

Change-Id: I208f2ed0ce288269708707f479e256d5f44e60b2
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1768185

commit_message:
Fix message handling with VirtualInterfacePlugException class usage

When a VNIC attach fails, the actual error message thrown from the
platform gets swallowed in the console showing only the generic
message in the exception class. This is due to the formatting
string passed to the exception class, though the
VirtualInterfacePlugException class definition doesn't accept one.

Change-Id: I18be7fc2284387d2f4d492ca68de6091f4bb8b66
Closes-Bug: #1796072

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-03-23 11:48:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> (2 comments)

In the master case, I'd just return the version of pbr, that's very explicit to have .dev there."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-10-08 13:12:37.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-23 11:27:12.000000000', 'message': "Generate more helpful version numbers

pbr bases its version numbers on git tags and automatically increments
these version numbers when you make commits to a branch. For example,
the version of a branch whose last tag is '17.0.0' will be '17.0.0',
while the version of that same branch with two additional commits will
be '17.0.1.dev2'. This is useful from a development context but is
rather unusual from a documentation perspective, particularly on stable
branches, as this is not seen as the documentation for a future version
but rather the modified documentation for a past version.

Modify the behavior of the feature to transform the 'N+1.devM' suffix to
'N-post', so '17.0.1.dev2' would become '17.0.0-post'.

Change-Id: I49cb01a34d069dc5f6d79c3b8e1307d1e0c78cf3
"}]
commit_message:
Generate more helpful version numbers

pbr bases its version numbers on git tags and automatically increments
these version numbers when you make commits to a branch. For example,
the version of a branch whose last tag is '17.0.0' will be '17.0.0',
while the version of that same branch with two additional commits will
be '17.0.1.dev2'. This is useful from a development context but is
rather unusual from a documentation perspective, particularly on stable
branches, as this is not seen as the documentation for a future version
but rather the modified documentation for a past version.

Modify the behavior of the feature to transform the 'N+1.devM' suffix to
'N-post', so '17.0.1.dev2' would become '17.0.0-post'.

Change-Id: I49cb01a34d069dc5f6d79c3b8e1307d1e0c78cf3

messages:
[{'account_id': 29191, 'date': '2018-09-25 13:34:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-09-25 13:34:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

commit_message:
Add action to generate root CA

Allows Vault to act as the root CA, rather than an intermediary CA.

Adds an action to fetch the root CA certificate after the fact.
Cleans up interaction with the relation by using the Endpoint refactor.
Adds config option to enable automatic generation of the root CA.
Increases timeout checking for Vault health to 5 min, since we've seen 4
minute startup times in CI.

Change-Id: Ic4e481452a46cc0500437113640509b387912ddc
Partial-Bug: 1776976
Depends-On: https://github.com/juju-solutions/interface-tls-certificates/pull/6
Signed-off-by: Cory Johns <johnsca@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-19 16:25:34.000000000', 'message': 'Add entry point to allow for oslo.policy CLI usage

The oslo.policy library exposes entry points so that users can
generate sample policy files and templates. The entry points do
expect some things to be done by the service in order to work,
though.

This commit adds an entry point for oslo.policy so that it can
consume an enforcer that has been initialized with mistrals
policies. The library will use this to generate useful things
for users like templates and sample policy files.

Change-Id: Ib442fbb79b5c237d634586c3169cf8c7f595da1c
Closes-Bug: 1793346
'}]
commit_message:
Add entry point to allow for oslo.policy CLI usage

The oslo.policy library exposes entry points so that users can
generate sample policy files and templates. The entry points do
expect some things to be done by the service in order to work,
though.

This commit adds an entry point for oslo.policy so that it can
consume an enforcer that has been initialized with mistrals
policies. The library will use this to generate useful things
for users like templates and sample policy files.

Change-Id: Ib442fbb79b5c237d634586c3169cf8c7f595da1c
Closes-Bug: 1793346

commit_message:
Update the CLI reference

Update the CLI reference according to the latest CLIs.

The CLI reference (doc/source/cli/nova.rst) has been imported
from openstack-manuals since If19cfcafc90fddb930c124a5b9845d4eae1f6093.
We can update the CLI reference synchronously with changing the CLIs
currently.
So remove the description of nova CLI version in the reference.

Change-Id: Icb97def5e4d65a31add7c60c205d5f9f0dfc4520
Closes-Bug: #1795283

subject: Fix assess status for super-conductor
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-03 13:51:56.000000000', 'message': 'Fix assess status for super-conductor

In a cells deployment its possible that the top-level
nova-cloud-controller will have no compute nodes associated with it.
This change fixes the work load status in that scenario.

There is also a drive by fix to return empty contexts for the cell
db and amqp contexts if the relation do not yet exists.

Change-Id: I67de8982ab8bbc635b98334cf967235e905ebac6
'}]
commit_message:
Fix assess status for super-conductor

In a cells deployment its possible that the top-level
nova-cloud-controller will have no compute nodes associated with it.
This change fixes the work load status in that scenario.

There is also a drive by fix to return empty contexts for the cell
db and amqp contexts if the relation do not yet exists.

Change-Id: I67de8982ab8bbc635b98334cf967235e905ebac6

commit_message:
SSH to node before validating services.

Having reply on SSH's port doesn't mean system is fully up
and user can log in.
To be sure system is up-n-running ssh to machine and run command
there.
Adjust syntx for 'jq' call.

Change-Id: I59387b201486fbc4c32c4146366881635ddca544
